content: The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. Many others were also prevented from joining the Department due to discriminatory screening processes. Congress played a role in these actions due to investigations into federal employees' sexual orientation. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State reported on the number of homosexuals fired each year due to congressional pressure. In the early 1990s, State personnel suspected of being gay were investigated and removed from government service as security risks. In the early 1990s, State personnel suspected of being gay were investigated and removed from government service as security risks. In response, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and President Clinton implemented measures to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation. Secretary of State John Kerry later apologized for the past practices and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations post-1950 to identify wrongful terminations due to sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made public within 270 days. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of reviews conducted by the Director General and submit reports to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will contact affected employees or their families, offer to change employment records, and provide a point of contact for testimonies of discrimination. The Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights will review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. It will receive oral testimony from affected employees or their families who experienced discrimination due to sexual orientation. The Board will also allow former employees to bring forth grievances if they believe they were terminated because of their sexual orientation. The Department of State will provide necessary information to prove wrongful termination claims. The Reconciliation Board will review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings and receive oral testimony from affected employees. The Department of State will provide information to prove wrongful termination claims within 150 days. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017, for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the State Department, acknowledging the historical mistreatment and expressing regret for the actions taken against them. The Department of State apologized for past discrimination against LGBTI employees, acknowledging wrong actions and reaffirming commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also formally apologized for encouraging the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies. The Secretary of State will establish a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center museum to ensure the history of this discriminatory episode is remembered. The exhibit will be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display material from oral testimonies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS. The Secretary of State must report to Congress within 100 days on countries denying visas to spouses of Foreign Service personnel based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include eliminating visa reciprocity with offending countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony on discrimination faced due to sexual orientation and submit annual reports to Congress with recommendations to prevent discrimination. The reports will remain private and accessible only to Members of Congress.
